metadata.description: SWOOD technical terms glossary for YouTube transcription correction

swood_design.label: SWOOD Design & Modeling
swood_design.description: Concepts related to the creation and structure of parametric 3D models, assemblies, and components within SWOOD Design.

cam_program.label: SWOOD CAM - Program & Tools
cam_program.description: Terms related to the setup and management of CAM programs, tools, aggregates, machines, and post-processors.

cam_operations.label: SWOOD CAM - Operations & Machining
cam_operations.description: Specific machining and nesting operations, strategies, and their associated parameters.

swood_report.label: SWOOD Report & Data Output
swood_report.description: Concepts related to the generation of production documents, data extraction, variables, and labeling.

swood_center.label: SWOOD Center & Automation
swood_center.description: Terms related to the automation of the design-to-production workflow using SWOOD Center.

libraries_config.label: Libraries & Configuration
libraries_config.description: Terms related to the management of SWOOD's data structure, libraries, and global settings.

core_ui.label: Core Concepts & UI
core_ui.description: Foundational terms and user interface elements within the SWOOD and SOLIDWORKS environment.

glossary.definition: An integrated CAD/CAM software suite within SOLIDWORKS, specialized for the design and manufacturing of wood products.
usage_examples: Today, we will be using the SWOOD software to design our cabinet.
Make sure your SWOOD license is activated before starting.
glossary.notes: Core software name. Highest priority for detection and correction due to high phonetic confusion.

glossary.definition: The CAD module of SWOOD used for creating intelligent, parametric 3D models of furniture and wood products.
usage_examples: First, we'll create the main structure in SWOOD Design.
The SWOOD Design libraries contain all our parametric components.

glossary.definition: The CAM module of SWOOD for creating CNC programs, defining toolpaths, and managing machining operations.
usage_examples: Now, let's switch to SWOOD CAM to apply the machinings.
Generate the G-code directly from SWOOD CAM.
glossary.notes: Key module name. High risk of 'CAM' being misinterpreted.

glossary.definition: A smart, parametric sub-assembly that adapts to a defined space within a cabinet, adding components and associated machinings.
usage_examples: We will insert a SWOODBox to add the drawer system.
The SWOODBox automatically creates the necessary drillings on adjacent panels.

glossary.definition: An automation module for batch processing SWOOD projects, generating production data from external sources without manual intervention.
usage_examples: The entire production order was generated overnight using SWOOD Center.
SWOOD Center connects to our ERP to automate the workflow.

glossary.definition: The central user directory containing all SWOOD libraries, configurations, tools, and post-processors.
usage_examples: Make sure your SWOODData folder is located on a shared network drive.
All custom materials are saved within the SWOODData directory.

glossary.definition: A dedicated support tool used to package and export project data for technical assistance.
usage_examples: Please use SWOODRx to send us your project files.
SWOODRx helps gather all the necessary information for support.

glossary.definition: A specific folder within SWOODData that stores custom property files for the SOLIDWORKS Property Tab Builder.
usage_examples: The custom property template is saved in the SWForm folder.
You can customize the SWForm files to match your company's standards.

glossary.definition: The primary parametric assembly in SWOOD Design, representing the main carcass or structure of a cabinet.
usage_examples: First, we define the main dimensions of the Frame.
All panels are constrained to the Frame's main planes.

glossary.definition: A feature and material type applied to panel edges, defining their finish, shape, and thickness properties.
usage_examples: We will apply a 2mm PVC Edgeband to the front edges.
The Edgeband can add to the final dimension of the panel.

glossary.definition: A library of definable post-design manufacturing steps, such as polishing or varnishing, applied to panels for cost calculation.
usage_examples: The Panel Process for lacquering adds 20 euros to the cost.
You can define multiple Panel Process steps for each material.

glossary.definition: A SWOOD Design feature for inserting and parametrically constraining a Frame into a larger master assembly.
usage_examples: Use the Layout Feature to position the kitchen cabinets.
The Layout Feature links the frame's dimensions to the sketch points.
glossary.notes: For creating large scenes or layouts.

glossary.definition: A SWOOD Design feature that automatically creates complex wood joints by detecting interferences between panels.
usage_examples: The Panel Joint tool is perfect for creating quick mortise and tenon connections.
We used a Panel Joint to create the halved joint for the shelf.

glossary.definition: A configuration file in SWOOD CAM that translates toolpaths into the specific machine code for a CNC machine.
usage_examples: You need to select the correct Post-Processor for your Biesse machine.
We can customize the Post-Processor to format the output file.
glossary.notes: Essential link between software and machine.

glossary.definition: A multi-spindle or angled tool holder for a CNC machine, defined in the SWOOD CAM library.
usage_examples: We need a horizontal Aggregate to drill the side holes.
The Aggregate library contains all our custom tool heads.

glossary.definition: An optimized SWOOD CAM contouring operation for nesting that minimizes tool retractions between parts to reduce machining time.
usage_examples: Enable the Staydown Contour to speed up the nesting cycle.
The Staydown Contour links toolpaths between adjacent parts.

glossary.definition: A specific SWOOD CAM pocketing operation designed to create mortises with radius compensation for precise joints.
usage_examples: Use the Mortising operation for all the door lock cutouts.
The Mortising toolpath is different from a standard pocket.

glossary.definition: The proprietary CAM software for HOMAG Group CNC machines, for which SWOOD CAM can generate specific compatible programs.
usage_examples: This program will be exported in WOODWOP format.
SWOOD generates a .mpr file for WOODWOP.

glossary.definition: A reusable piece of leftover material from a nested panel, which SWOOD CAM can track and manage.
usage_examples: The nesting generated a large Offcut that we can use later.
Manage the Offcut inventory in the board library.

glossary.definition: A powerful reporting feature to classify components based on rules, enabling the generation of specific lists (e.g., hardware).
usage_examples: We created a Typed Object to list all the Blum hardware separately.
The condition for this Typed Object is based on a custom property.

glossary.definition: A command used in SWOOD Report templates to iterate through a list of objects and display their data.
usage_examples: Use a Loop-on command to list all the panels in the report.
Inside the Loop-on block, we will add the panel dimensions.

glossary.definition: A command in SWOOD Report templates that defines for which object a specific document or file should be generated.
usage_examples: The Process-on command is set to 'Panel' to generate one label per panel.
We use Process-on 'Program' to export individual CNC files.

glossary.definition: The primary text-based configuration file that defines the structure, content, and behavior of a SWOOD Report.
usage_examples: You can edit the Report.cfg file to add a new document type.
All the report variables are defined in the Report.cfg.

glossary.definition: The configuration file for the SWOOD CAM module, controlling default behaviors and settings for manufacturing.
usage_examples: Default tool speeds are set in the SWOODCAM.cfg.
To change the simulation colors, edit the SWOODCAM.cfg file.

glossary.definition: The configuration file for the SWOOD Design module, managing settings related to modeling and libraries.
usage_examples: The behavior of the Panel Joint can be configured in SWOODDesign.cfg.
We added a new panel type in the SWOODDesign.cfg.

glossary.definition: The SOLIDWORKS design tree located on the left panel, which displays all SWOOD features, parts, and assemblies.
usage_examples: You can see the SWOODBox feature in the FeatureManager.
Right-click on the panel in the FeatureManager to edit it.

glossary.definition: The SOLIDWORKS side panel on the right where SWOOD libraries (Frames, SWOODBoxes, Materials) are accessed.
usage_examples: Drag a material from the SWOOD Task Pane onto the panel.
Open the SWOOD libraries in the Task Pane.

glossary.definition: The SOLIDWORKS interface on the left panel that appears when creating or editing a SWOOD feature to configure its parameters.
usage_examples: Configure the panel's dimensions in the PropertyManager.
The PropertyManager allows you to select the connector type.

glossary.definition: The main SOLIDWORKS toolbar at the top of the screen where the SWOOD CAM and SWOOD Design tabs are located.
usage_examples: Click the 'Create a new panel' button in the CommandManager.
Switch to the SWOOD CAM tab in the CommandManager.

glossary.definition: A specific connector system from Lamello, machined in SWOOD CAM using a disc-type cutter to create detachable furniture joints.
usage_examples: Use the automatic Clamex operation to machine the grooves for the connectors.
The 'Clamex with milling tool' is required when an angular gear unit is not available for the saw.
glossary.notes: Brand name connector (Lamello) with specific machining requirements. High risk of misspelling or phonetic confusion.

glossary.definition: A wood joint creating a slot in one panel to receive another, implemented as a specific connector type in SWOOD Design.
usage_examples: We will connect the shelf to the side panel using a DADO joint.
The DADO connector automatically generates the required groove.
glossary.notes: A fundamental woodworking joint implemented as a SWOOD connector. High risk of phonetic confusion with the word 'data'.

glossary.definition: A specific brand of tool-free, push-fit connectors for creating invisible, strong joints, available as a connector type in SWOOD Design.
usage_examples: The assembly uses OVVO connectors for quick, tool-free installation on site.
You need to select the correct OVVO machining profile in SWOOD CAM.
glossary.notes: Brand name for a specific push-fit connector. Prone to phonetic misinterpretation as 'ovo'.

glossary.definition: A brand of joinery systems providing specific connector types, like the biscuit joint, for panel assembly in SWOOD Design.
usage_examples: Use a Lamello connector to create a strong biscuit joint between the two panels.
The Clamex is part of the Lamello P-System, requiring a specific toolpath.
glossary.notes: A specific brand name for joinery systems. It's both a library category and a type of connector.

glossary.definition: A major hardware supplier providing a wide range of components like drawer systems, hinges, and connectors available in SWOOD Design libraries.
usage_examples: For this project, we will use the Hettich drawer system for the main cabinets.
You can find all the Hettich components in their dedicated library folder.
glossary.notes: A major multi-product hardware supplier (connectors, drawers, hinges). Its name can be misspelled or misheard.

glossary.definition: A prominent hardware manufacturer known for its drawer systems, hinges, and lift systems, integrated into dedicated SWOOD Design libraries.
usage_examples: This cabinet design uses the Blum LEGRABOX drawer system.
We will use the Blum Import feature to bring in the configuration from their website.
glossary.notes: A key multi-product hardware supplier with a dedicated import tool. High brand recognition. Can be confused with 'bloom' or 'plumb'.

glossary.definition: The French software development company and publisher of the entire SWOOD suite, specializing in woodworking solutions.
usage_examples: The SWOOD software suite is developed and owned by EFICAD.
For licensing inquiries, you should contact EFICAD directly.
glossary.notes: The parent company and publisher of SWOOD.

glossary.definition: The 3D CAD software platform on which the SWOOD suite operates as a fully integrated add-in.
usage_examples: SWOOD is a fully integrated add-in for SolidWorks.
You can see the SWOOD features directly in the SolidWorks FeatureManager tree.
glossary.notes: The foundational CAD software for SWOOD. Included because it is a fully integrated add-in and its UI elements are essential to describe workflows.

glossary.definition: A hardware component allowing doors to pivot, typically inserted and machined via a dedicated SWOODBox in SWOOD Design.
usage_examples: Now we will insert the hinges into the door using a dedicated SWOODBox.
The properties of the hinges can be adjusted after insertion.
glossary.notes: A fundamental hardware component in cabinet design. The variants 'ines' and 'inches' are key phonetic errors to catch.
